title: The Sign of Immanuel
shortSummary: Isaiah 7 recounts the political crisis during King Ahaz’s reign when Syria and Israel threaten Judah. God, through Isaiah, reassures Ahaz of His sovereign protection and offers a miraculous sign—the prophecy of Immanuel—affirming God’s presence and ultimate deliverance despite immediate threats.
timeline: c. 735 BC - Syro-Ephraimite War during the reign of King Ahaz of Judah

keyCharacters.name: Ahaz
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah who faces a coalition threat from Syria and Israel and struggles with fear and unbelief.

keyCharacters.name: Isaiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet sent by God to encourage Ahaz and deliver God's message and sign of hope.

keyCharacters.name: Rezin
keyCharacters.description: King of Syria, one of the leaders of the coalition against Judah.

keyCharacters.name: Pekah
keyCharacters.description: Son of Remaliah and king of Israel, allied with Syria against Judah.

definitions.definition: Meaning 'God with us,' a prophetic name symbolizing God's presence and deliverance.
In Hebrew 'almah,' referring to a young woman of marriageable age who has not had sexual relations; significant in prophecy.
A water channel or aqueduct near Jerusalem, a meeting place mentioned as the location where Isaiah meets Ahaz.

definitions.term: Two tails of these smoking firebrands
definitions.definition: A metaphor describing the fierce anger and destructive threat posed by Rezin of Syria and Pekah of Israel.

outline.heading: The Threat Against Judah
outline.description: Syria and Israel form an alliance to attack Jerusalem, causing fear in King Ahaz and his people. This sets the stage for God's intervention.

outline.heading: God’s Assurance and Prophecy
outline.description: God declares through Isaiah that the plans of Syria and Israel will fail and foretells the downfall of Ephraim within sixty-five years, emphasizing the need for faith.

outline.heading: The Sign of Immanuel
outline.description: God invites Ahaz to ask for a sign, but Ahaz refuses. Nevertheless, God promises a sign: a virgin will conceive and bear a son named Immanuel, symbolizing God's presence and future deliverance.

outline.heading: Judgment and Restoration Imagery
outline.description: God warns of coming judgment through the Assyrian invasion but also describes a future restoration where the land will be transformed, highlighting both discipline and hope.

application: Trust God’s promises even when circumstances seem threatening, remembering His sovereignty over all nations.
Do not let fear drive you to unbelief; instead, seek God’s guidance and rest in His peace.
Be attentive to God’s signs and messages, recognizing His presence with His people through all trials.
Understand that God’s discipline is purposeful and leads to eventual restoration and blessing.

keyVerses.text: Therefore the Lord himself shall give you a sign; Behold, a virgin shall conceive, and bear a son, and shall call his name Immanuel.
keyVerses.significance: This verse is the central prophetic promise of God's presence and future salvation through the Messiah.

keyVerses.text: Thus saith the Lord GOD, It shall not stand, neither shall it come to pass.
keyVerses.significance: God’s sovereign declaration that the enemy’s plans against Judah will fail, encouraging faith in His protection.

keyVerses.text: And the head of Ephraim is Samaria, and the head of Samaria is Remaliah's son. If ye will not believe, surely ye shall not be established.
keyVerses.significance: A solemn warning about the necessity of faith for stability and security.
